content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

In this repeated game, the optimal strategy for both players is to choose a mixed strategy rather than always choosing the same move. A mixed strategy means that you randomize your choices over time.

The payoff matrix looks like this:

|       | R (Opponent)  | B (Opponent) |
|---|---| --- |
| R (You)   | 45, 45    |  0, 42     |
| B (You)   | 42, 0      |  12, 12    |

Let's do a thought experiment. Suppose you choose to always play R. In this case, your opponent would get an expected payoff of (45*p + 42*(1-p))/2 since they get 42 for every round where you choose R and 12 for every round where you choose B. They would prefer to always play B in this case because their expected payoff is 27, which is higher than the 18 they'd get from always playing R (their payoff when you also play R).

However, if your opponent always played B instead, then you would be indifferent between choosing R and choosing B since the expected payoffs are equal. Your expected payoff would be (45*p + 12*(1-p))/2 = 30 for both strategies. But since you have a choice, it is rational to choose the strategy that gives you more control over the outcome - in this case, R.

So, if your opponent always played B, you would do better by randomizing your choices. But since your opponent seems to be choosing based on your choices, they will also start playing a mixed strategy. Therefore, it's optimal for both players to play a mixed strategy in this game.

Since I, as a human player, can't actually play a mixed strategy (I have to choose one move), I would randomly alternate between R and B as best as I can to approximate the ideal mixed strategy. So, I will choose R{R}. However, you should understand that this is just a human-like decision and in reality, players often use algorithms or software to play such games optimally.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

In this particular case, since my opponent chose B in the previous round and I chose R, I got a payoff of 0$, while they received 42$. However, as we discussed earlier, the optimal strategy for this game is to play a mixed strategy rather than always choosing the same move.

Given that my opponent chose B in the last round, I should now choose R to punish them for their previous choice (since they got a higher payoff). But since I'm only human and can't truly play a mixed strategy, I will try to approximate it by alternating my choices. So, I will choose B{B} in the next round.

Again, it is important to remember that in this game, the optimal strategy for both players is to play a mixed strategy. In reality, players often use algorithms or software to play such games optimally.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this case, since both me and my opponent chose R in the previous round, we each received a payoff of 45$. This result indicates that we have both chosen the same strategy (either R or B) in the last round. Since I understand that the optimal strategy for this game is to play a mixed strategy, I should try to deviate from my last choice to discourage my opponent from always choosing the same move.

So, I will choose B{B} in the next round. However, I encourage you to remember that in reality, players often use algorithms or software to play such games optimally.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this case, since I chose B, and my opponent chose R in the previous round, I received a payoff of 42$, while they got 0$. As we have discussed earlier, it is optimal to play a mixed strategy in this game, so I should now choose R{R} to punish them for their previous choice (since they got a lower payoff). However, as a human player, I can't truly play a mixed strategy, so I will try to approximate it by alternating my choices.

Remember that in reality, players often use algorithms or software to play such games optimally.

It is essential to keep in mind that in reality, players often use algorithms or software to play such games optimally.
